body_content.explanation: to write your name, usually on a written or printed document, to show that you agree with its contents or have written or created it yourself:
examples: to sign a letter/cheque/contract/lease/agreement
Sign here, please.
He signed his name at the end of the letter.
He signed himself "Mark Taylor".
She said the painting was by Picasso, but it wasn't signed.

body_content.explanation: in sport, to make a legal written agreement to employ a player:
examples: The team has just signed a new player.

body_content.explanation: to give an order or information, or make a request, using hand and body movements:
examples: He signed for/to the waiter to bring him another drink.
He signed to the waiter that he wanted another drink.

body_content.explanation: to use sign language (= language used by people who cannot hear or talk)
a notice giving information, directions, a warning, etc.:
examples: a road sign
a shop sign

body_content.explanation: a movement of the body that gives information or an instruction:
examples: She pointed to her watch as a sign that it was getting late and she wanted to leave.
He made/gave a sign to his boyfriend to stop talking.
The priest made the sign of the cross (= made the shape of a cross by moving his hand between four points on his chest) when he entered the church.

body_content.explanation: something showing that something else exists or might happen or exist in the future:
examples: His inability to handle the situation is a sure sign of weakness.
The fact that he's eating more is a sign that he's feeling better.
I've searched for my hat, but there's no sign of it anywhere (= I can't find it).
There was no sign of life in the building (= there seemed to be no one in it).
Billy's work at school has shown signs of improvement this year.
There is every sign that/All the signs are that the worst is over.

body_content.explanation: a written or printed mark that has a standard meaning:
examples: + and - are mathematical signs.
£ is the sign for the British pound.
